Text: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is a violation of int'l law. I'm pleased @POTUS has responded to Putin’s heinous aggression against the Ukrainian people in announcing this first round of sanctions. We must continue to stand w/ our allies in holding Putin & his cronies accountable.

Hot tip from my staff: Run, don’t walk to @AlexEdelman’s brilliant Just for Us, his comedic take on the very serious topics of white supremacy and antisemitism. It’s moving from @CherryLnTheatre to @sohoplayhouse for an extended run.  I’m going soon! https://t.co/n9s0pjzunf

The threats facing minority institutions are varied, and the solutions are complex. Nevertheless, we must begin by understanding the challenges we face and examining a range of proposals for how best to respond. 

Read my statement: 
https://t.co/57y4kVeuIQ

We must combat this. Too many in recent years have felt the pain & fear of hate-fueled violence. It has deepened existing wounds that have developed over centuries of bigotry and hate directed at them. And now, we face increasing threats of domestic terrorism in the U.S.

At base, domestic terrorism isolates us—not just by inflicting violence on our communities, but also by defining individuals who are members of those communities as ‘other.’ Domestic terrorists want to force us into that frame—a narrative of ‘us’ and ‘them.
HAPPENING NOW: @HouseJudiciary is examining domestic terrorism and the rise of violence against minority institutions. https://t.co/PWTtNs92Fb

We have an obligation to ensure that all Americans have ready access to quality medical care today and in the future. We must ensure that our immigration system facilitates—rather than blocks—the admission of the best doctors from around the world.

https://t.co/3x27wRjh7x

Unfortunately, our outdated immigration system only adds to the problem. Although foreign-educated physicians can come to the United States to complete their medical training, their temporary visa options are limited.

Even before the pandemic, experts were projecting that our country would experience a significant shortage of physicians in the near future. The onset of COVID has taken an enormous mental and physical toll on physicians in the United States, exacerbating existing shortages.
This hearing also examines how our broken immigration system has made it difficult for such physicians to remain in our communities and continue to provide critical care to those in need.

Our country has long relied on foreign-educated physicians to supplement the domestic physician workforce. Today’s @HouseJudiciary hearing explores the role that immigrant physicians play in the provision of health care in the United States. https://t.co/UOt3ZQCZu2

Today at 2 pm ET, @HouseJudiciary will hold a hearing to explore the role of immigrant physicians in the U.S. healthcare system and how our current immigration laws impact the recruitment and retention of physicians.

Follow along:
https://t.co/v4c8qS4jOj

This legislation ends this unjust system in which American companies are better off retaliating against victims of sexual assault than taking responsibility and holding perpetrators responsible for their horrific actions.

This is a significant step forward for survivors and millions of Americans who have been denied their day in court because of forced arbitration clauses.

I am proud that this bill passed with bipartisan support, sending a clear message that perpetrators will be held accountable.

Last November, @HouseJudiciary heard powerful testimony from four survivors of sexual assault and sexual harassment about their harrowing experiences and the deep wounds they continue to carry with them to this day.  It was a hearing none of us will forget.

The House just passed H.R. 4445, the Ending Forced Arbitration of Sexual Assault and Sexual Harassment Act. This bill would restore access to justice for survivors of sexual assault or harassment who are forced into secretive arbitration processes that are stacked against them. https://t.co/ut3FgTowIo

It is time for us to act and right the wrongs caused by the failed war on drugs.

Legislation to help ensure that more women, people of color, and other disadvantaged groups have access to the patent system for their inventions, and legislation to ensure that our federal agencies have the resources to properly enforce our antitrust laws was also included.

I’m particularly proud that the SHOP SAFE Act, a bipartisan proposal that combats the sale of harmful counterfeit products online, was included in this package. By removing counterfeits from online marketplaces, consumers can be confident that what they see is what they will get.

@HouseDemocrats just passed the #AmericaCOMPETES Act which will make historic investments to preserve high-quality jobs and support historic economic growth by enhancing protections for consumers, promoting competition and improving scientific research and innovation.

We will also examine how the BOP is working to improve conditions in its prisons, an issue that I have long fought for.

Unfortunately, that is not always the case. My bill will help restore the original purpose of the National Wildlife Refuge System as a sanctuary for wildlife by prohibiting the use of body-gripping traps on these public, protected lands.

This morning, I submitted the following statement for the record to @NRDems about my Refuge from Cruel Trapping Act. 
 
When folks visit their local National Wildlife Refuges, most expect to view wildlife without fear that they or their pets will fall victim to a dangerous trap.

Sadly, that seems like ancient history now.

To remain a true democracy, we must resist attempts to poison our election machinery with partisan interests that disenfranchise minority voters and deny or dilute votes.

Until relatively recently, both parties shared a commitment to supporting the Voting Rights Act.  As @POTUS pointed out in his recent speech in Atlanta, the Senate voted 98 to 0 to reauthorize the Voting Rights Act in 2006.

This hearing comes at a critical point in our history — legislation to protect the fundamental right to vote in fair elections, free from racial discrimination, faces united obstruction from @SenateGOP.
Today, the @HouseJudiciary Subcommittee on the Constitution, Civil Rights, and Civil Liberties is holding a hearing on "Voter Suppression and Continuing Threats to Democracy." https://t.co/naQ9vdUko9

In nearly every state, they have introduced bills that make it harder to vote, particularly for people of color.

This is beyond unacceptable. We will not give up on passing voting rights legislation and I urge my colleagues in the Senate to reconsider and do what is right.

As I have said before, our democracy is not guaranteed and we must make the choice to defend it everyday.

Unfortunately, the GOP has chosen to suppress access to the ballot box, undermining this fundamental right.

Last night, we again saw critical voting rights legislation stall due to a small group of Senators.

The right to vote is the foundational cornerstone of our democracy and it is disappointing to see the Senate fail to do what is necessary to safeguard it.

I applaud the Biden-Harris Administration for taking critical actions to remedy America’s consolidation problem, and we must continue to do more.

Read my full statement from today's hearing:
https://t.co/XWguZ90ucl

Corporate concentration in food markets is bad for Americans. 

Throughout the pandemic, businesses have earned record profits while people have seen their paychecks buying less. This is nothing short of pandemic profiteering, at the expense of everyone else.

Due to unchecked consolidation, a few corporations own every link in the food supply chain. The beef, poultry, and pork processing markets are each dominated by four huge corporations. The grocery retail market similarly is concentrated in the hands of just a few companies.

Anyone who has gone to the grocery store recently has seen the price of food go up, with the price of meat, poultry, and eggs rising at a clip that far surpasses the rest. Why? Because those are the markets with the fewest competitors; dominated by just a few corporate giants.

Today, @HouseJudiciary is holding a hearing to examine how big corporations are raising the prices of food all while bringing in record profits. 

Follow along:
https://t.co/kR6tvRq31w

Thank you, @POTUS, for taking the critical step today to call for changing the filibuster to ensure the Senate passes the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act and restores the Voting Rights Act.

But now, Senate Republicans have made it clear that they have no intention of working with us in good faith to ensure the right to vote is protected. So it is time to work around them to safeguard our democracy for future generations.

Since the passage of the VRA of 1965, protecting Americans’ right to vote had not been a partisan issue. In 2006, the Senate supported the same principles in the John R. Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act when it voted 98-0 to reauthorize the VRA.
Yet despite these sacrifices, anti-voter laws are being pushed through state legislatures by radicals who seek to deny millions of Americans access to the ballot box.
As @POTUS and @VP discussed today, since the foundation of our nation, millions of our fellow citizens have fought and died to access the right to vote— our most fundamental freedom.

We have a duty to protect the right to vote.

We need the Senate to act and pass critical voting rights legislation this week, like the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act. #JLVRAA
Especially during these challenging times, it's more important than ever to come together as a community. Glad I could help! https://t.co/unigEW0GCf

On this solemn anniversary, I spoke at MoveOn's #January6th Vigil for Democracy on the Upper West Side to commemorate the violent attack on our Capitol.

Let this day remind us that we must actively defend our democracy from those who would silence the voice of the people. https://t.co/tc0JcjuHMj

Now more than ever we need the Senate to join us in passing transformative legislation, like the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act. 

We must safeguard our ability to determine our own future through the ballot box and close the door on election conspiracies and lies.

These violent insurrectionists aimed for the heart of our democratic process. For more than 200 years this nation has been guided by the will of the people through free and fair elections. As citizens and representatives of the people, we have a duty to defend our right to vote.

As the @January6thCmte and @TheJusticeDept continue to investigate and hold accountable those who assaulted our democracy, there are things Congress must do in the short term, namely secure our elections from future attacks like the one attempted on Jan. 6. https://t.co/t2HoJA0wPf

We cannot ignore the things we learned on January 6th. Our democracy is not guaranteed and we must work to protect it each and every day.

We have more work to do, and we must continue to send a strong message that these actions have no place in our democracy.

We must ensure something like this never happens again. But the reality is, the GOP has refused to confront the ongoing threats created by Donald Trump. Instead, they have spent the past year going to the states to make voting laws more restrictive while peddling misinformation.

One year ago today, a group of domestic terrorists fueled by Donald Trump attempted, and nearly succeeded, at overturning a fair and free election.

Not only were they looking to halt the peaceful transfer of power but they actively sought to harm lawmakers and their staff.

I also support the proposed Interborough passenger line along the Bay Ridge Right of Way. We can do both — provide for freight and passengers. I will work with the Governor and MTA to make sure these projects move forward.

The NY metropolitan area represents the largest consumer market in the nation, with over 320 million tons of freight transported through our region annually.

That is why I led my NY and NJ colleagues last year in sending a letter to @SecretaryPete advocating for this project. https://t.co/XRpp5J2hdW

NYC is the only major city that is not directly connected to its national freight rail network, creating a tremendous modal imbalance, resulting in severe highway congestion, undermining economic prosperity, harming public health, and damaging our environment.

Today, @GovKathyHochul announced that she has directed the Port Authority to do the environmental reviews on the Cross Harbor Rail Freight Tunnel. This is a vital project for our region. 

https://t.co/1gCqkOeGcY

We now have the opportunity to change that.

In the name of all the victims of lynching throughout our history, I urge my colleagues once again to support this important legislation and join me in demanding national accountability for racial violence.

The first federal antilynching legislation was introduced in 1900—almost 120 years ago—by Congressman George Henry White, the only African American Member of Congress at that time.  Unfortunately, neither his bill, nor any other antilynching bills have managed to pass Congress.

Following the brutal murder of Ahmaud Arbery, which has been cast as a modern lynching by civil rights advocates, it is apparent that we need to create a lynching offense under federal law to bare the full force of our justice system against those who commit such horrific acts.

Today, @HouseJudiciary is marking up the Emmett Till Antilynching Act. This is a long-overdue legislation that would explicitly designate lynching as a hate crime under federal law. 
 
Read my full opening statement for the Emmett Till Antilynching Act: https://t.co/KeXenamc6h
